paper_abstract: A graph-theoretic account of logics is explored based on the general notion of in-graph (i.e: a graph where each edge can have a finite sequence of nodes as source). Signatures, interpretation structures and deduction systems are seen as multi-graphs (in-graphs). After defining a category freely generated by a in-graph. formulas and expressions in general can be seen as morphisms. Moreover, derivations involving rule instantiation are also morphisms. Soundness and completeness theorems are proved. As a consequence of the generality of the approach our results apply to very different logics encompassing, among others, substructural logics as well as logics with non-deteministic semantics, and subsume all logics endowed with an algebraic semantics,
